chunks.en: You are in the left lane with a GPS speed of 120. A car is rapidly approaching you from behind. Do you yield or not?
The posts discussing highway driving these past few days have been a real clash of ideas, which has greatly shocked me.
The question in the title is something many people probably encounter. How would you handle it?

chunks.en:
If you feel you're already driving at the speed limit and don't yield, and then car after car rapidly approaches from behind and everyone overtakes you from the right,
and some drivers get angry that you didn't yield and quickly merge from the right after overtaking to try and scare you, what would you do then?
If I'm already driving at the speed limit, I won't yield if there's room to overtake in other lanes. If there's no room to overtake, I'll speed up to let them pass.
Where do all these armchair drivers come from? A car that can quickly approach you will have already completed the lane change to prepare for overtaking before you even react.
The comments section amazes me. Since when does the rule about the overtaking lane depend on your speed? Even if you're driving at 150, you shouldn't occupy the overtaking lane.
After reading a round of comments, no wonder there are so many idiots on the road...

Yield if you can. No need to be stubborn or argue over winning or losing. It can avoid a large number of traffic accidents. Also, with a speed limit of 120, traffic regulations tacitly allow you to exceed it by 10%, so there's really no need to be so serious.

The most ridiculous thing is that some people actually think that 120 is already very dangerous and that the car is already out of control... Seriously, what kind of industrial garbage are you driving?

chunks.en: @anonydmer > Even if you're driving 150, you shouldn't occupy the overtaking lane. In China in 2025, what is an overtaking lane? Does traffic law even contain the phrase 'occupying the overtaking lane'? You can't let your imagined rules override official regulations.

If a car is approaching quickly from behind, your correct response is to do nothing, maintain your speed, stay in your lane, and don't accelerate or decelerate. The car behind will overtake if it can, and if it can't, it will slow down. Any action you take will make it more difficult for them to judge.

chunks.en: If the road ahead is clear and you're driving 120 in the far-left lane, you're what I call a 'grandma car.' Grandma cars, please move to the right lane. If there's a group of cars ahead and you're driving 120 in the far-left lane, I won't overtake you, and you don't need to yield.
I wouldn't yield in this situation. Let them change lanes themselves.

Damn, so many people really don't understand the laws and regulations. There's no concept of an overtaking lane anymore. Both the left and right lanes can be used for overtaking. The speed limit on most highways is 120. Speeding less than 10% over is generally okay. As long as you're not below the minimum speed limit, you can drive in any lane you want. But be careful not to drive side by side. Driving side by side for a long time is actually illegal.

I would yield. Because individual cars frequently changing lanes in front of you is very unsafe. Driving safety is the most important thing. Being stubborn isn't worth mentioning. If they're willing to speed and break the law, that's their business.
@imshawer What traffic law tacitly allows exceeding the speed limit by 10%? If the speed limit is 120 and you drive 121 and have an accident, you are responsible for speeding.

Since when can you righteously crawl in the leftmost lane at 120 and obstruct traffic? Of course you have to yield if you're slower than the flow of traffic. If I'm cruising at 136 on the highway and a car comes up behind me in the left lane, I'll also yield without hesitation.

This is a false proposition. First of all, driving side by side is illegal. If there's room to overtake, you don't need to yield. Changing lanes only increases your own safety risk. Let the car behind change lanes itself. Also, pay attention to the state of the car behind you. Don't actually let the car behind rear-end you. If there's no room to overtake and you yourself are blocked by a pack of cars, you don't need to yield, and there's no feasibility to yield. If there's no room to overtake and you're illegally driving side by side, then of course you should speed up or slow down as soon as possible to make room for overtaking, and there's no need to change lanes. Driving safety is the most important thing. In an emergency situation, it's okay to speed appropriately, cross lines, or even drive in the emergency lane. Don't consider what's legal or illegal. Is a law more important than your life? Both the left and right highway lanes can be used for overtaking. There's long been no mention of an overtaking lane. As long as you don't affect the passage of other vehicles, drive in whatever lane you want. There's no claim to a long-term occupation of the leftmost lane; this applies to trucks because they affect the movement of other vehicles.

I wouldn't stay at 120 in the left lane all the time. It blocks the road and reduces traffic efficiency. Rules are just a moral baseline, just like the OP said, other cars overtaking from the right and scaring you isn't illegal either ğŸ˜†.

It mainly depends on the situation in my right lane. If there's no car to the right, I won't change lanes, and the car behind will change lanes itself. If there's a car in the right lane and it's going about the same speed as me, I'll see how it goes and change lanes to avoid driving side by side.

1. Yield if there's no car to the right. 2. If there's a car to the right and no speed camera, speed up and change lanes to the right to let them pass. 3. If there's a car to the right and a speed camera, let them pass after passing the speed camera.
1. If I'm going 120, I don't yield. 2. If I feel a safety risk, I yield.
I wouldn't stay in the left lane for long, especially at a speed of 120, which is already dangerous. I try to stay in the middle lane.
